text: Recommended by Anne M. Larson There are a growing number of cases detailing acute hepatic necrosis in patients taking black cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa), an over-the-counter herbal supplement for management of menopausal symptoms.
label: Pathology
Herb name
Pathology

text: Our aim is to illustrate two cases of liver injury following the use of black cohosh characterized by histopathological features mimicking autoimmune hepatitis.
label: Pathology
Herb name
Pathology

text: Both patients reported black cohosh use for at least six months and had no evidence of another cause of liver disease.
label: Herb name
Duration
Pathology

text: Their liver biopsies showed a component of centrilobular necrosis consistent with severe drug-induced liver injury.
label: Pathology

text: In addition, the biopsies showed characteristics of autoimmune-like liver injury with an interface hepatitis dominated by plasma cells.
label: Pathology
Pathology

text: Although serum markers for autoimmune hepatitis were not particularly elevated, both patients responded to corticosteroids, supporting an immune-mediated component to the liver injury.
label: Pathology
Drug
Pathology

text: Liver injury following the use of black cohosh should be included in the list of differential diagnoses for chronic hepatitis with features mimicking autoimmune hepatitis.
label: Pathology

text: Black cohosh (Cimicifuga racemosa) is an herbal supplement that is sold over-the-counter for management of menopausal symptoms, menstrual irregularities, and arthritis.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Pathology
Pathology

text: There are now a number of manuscripts indicating liver injury from black cohosh [1–7].
label: Pathology
Herb name

text: Here, we present two patients who developed a drug-induced liver injury following the use of black cohosh characterized by centrilobular necrosis and histologic features mimicking autoimmune hepatitis (AIH) who improved with corticosteroid therapy.
label: Pathology
Herb name

text: The case series was approved by the Institutional Review Board at the University of Illinois at Chicago.
A 42-year-old woman presented to her primary care provider with a two-month history of progressive malaise, nausea, vomiting, and dizziness.

text: A liver biopsy was performed which prompted a referral to the liver center at the University of Illinois.

The liver biopsy was remarkable for necrosis around terminal hepatic venules, lobular disarray, mild ballooning, apoptosis, Kupffer cell reactivity, mild cholangiolar proliferation, and interface hepatitis remarkable for numerous plasma cells and eosinophils.
label: Pathology

text: A repeat antismooth muscle antibody was normal at 1 : 20.
Prednisone treatment was initiated.
label: Drug

text: A follow-up liver biopsy was performed after three months.
label: Duration

text: At this time, the liver histology demonstrated chronic hepatitis with fibroinflammatory expansion of portal tracts by moderate plasma cell rich interface hepatitis, rare periportal hepatocyte apoptosis, and mild cholangiolar proliferation (Figures 1(a) and 1(b)).
label: Pathology
Pathology
Parameter

text: The patient was started on azathioprine.
label: Drug

text: Her liver enzymes returned to normal values within five months with an ALT of 30 U/L, AST of 29 U/L, ALP 36 U/L, and a total bilirubin of 0.9 mg/dL.

text: A repeat liver biopsy after fifteen months showed marked improvement with only minimal portal lymphocytes and no other significant histopathological changes.

A 53-years-old woman presented to our liver center for evaluation of elevated liver enzymes detected at a health screening fair four months earlier.
label: Age
Sex

text: She had no risk factors for viral hepatitis, no family history of liver disease, and denied any alcohol consumption.
label: Pathology

text: Although she was initially asymptomatic, she developed right upper quadrant abdominal pain, fatigue, and lower extremity edema by the time of her presentation.
label: Pathology

text: Her medications within the past year included dicyclomine for abdominal cramps as needed, an herbal supplement which contains soy protein and black cohosh for menopausal symptoms, and occasional over the counter nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) for pain.

text: The clinicopathological features of Case 2 are illustrated in Tables 1, 2, and 4.
The Naranjo causality score for adverse drug reactions [8] was applied to the cases described here.
label: Pathology

text: As shown in Table 5, the current case studies individually achieved a Naranjo score of 3 and were both categorized as “possible adverse drug reaction”, in a scale encompassing a minimum score of zero, or “doubtful adverse drug reaction” to a maximum score of ≥9, or “definite adverse drug reaction.” While the current case studies showed histopathological features of autoimmune hepatitis, neither fulfilled a diagnosis of “probable AIH” or “definite AIH” based on the Hennes simplified criteria for diagnosis of AIH [10].
label: Pathology
Pathology

Pathology
Pathology

text: Briefly, Case 1 had an ANA titer of up to 1 : 80 (score 2), no available immunoglobulin titers (no score), a liver histology compatible with AIH (score 1), and absence of viral hepatitis (score 2), with a total score of 5.
label: Parameter
Pathology
Pathology

text: Case 2 had a score of 1-0-1-2 = 4, on a scale where a score of ≥6 was designated “probable AIH”, and ≥7 as “definite AIH.” Botanical dietary supplements are used commonly in the United States and are generally perceived to be safe [11].
label: Pathology
Pathology

text: In one study, nearly one half of persons reported use of at least one agent to their primary provider [12].
A major difficulty in studying black cohosh is uncertainty regarding the composition of the various black cohosh products.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: Black cohosh itself contains a number of secondary compounds including phenolic derivatives and triterpene glycosides [13].
label: Herb name
Herb name
Herb name

text: Phytoestrogens were postulated to play a role in black cohosh binding to estrogen receptors, but the presence of these compounds is controversial.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Target

text: In one study, chromatographic analysis of 11 commercial black cohosh products showed that three were actually Asian Actea species [13].
label: Herb name
Ethnic group
Herb name

text: An analysis of the remaining eight products found variability in the composition of triterpene glycosides and phenolic constituents.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: More importantly, not a single product contained a phytoestrogen.
label: Herb name

text: Thus, the mechanism by which black cohosh might impact on alleviating menopausal symptoms is not well understood.
label: Herb name
Pathology

text: Other possibilities include binding to yet-to-be-defined receptors or effects on the central nervous system [14].
Whether black cohosh is effective in controlling vasomotor symptoms of menopause is controversial as well.
label: Herb name
Pathology

text: The American College of Obstetrics and Gynecology included black cohosh as a possible remedy for the vasomotor symptoms of menopause [15].
label: Ethnic group
Herb name
Pathology

text: A large randomized-blinded trial of one-year duration found no difference between black cohosh and placebo in controlling vasomotor symptoms [16].
label: Study
Duration
Herb name

text: Moreover, a recent review did not recommend long-term use due to the absence of safety evaluation [17].
There are a growing number of case reports of hepatotoxicity in patients taking black cohosh (Table 6) [1–7].
label: Pathology
Herb name

text: Most described acute hepatic necrosis, although three articles of them detailed a case with clinical features of autoimmune hepatitis after black cohosh use [1, 2, 5].
label: Pathology
Pathology
Herb name

text: The clinicopathological features of the cases in the current series have a fascinating combination of findings.
Both patients presented with an acute hepatitis displaying prominent centrilobular necrosis consistent with severe drug-induced liver injury.
label: Pathology
Pathology

text: While autoantibodies were low titer or absent, the histology showed characteristics of autoimmune hepatitis with a plasma cell rich interface and lobular hepatitis.
label: Parameter
Pathology
Pathology

text: In addition, both patients responded to corticosteroids, supporting an immune mediated component to the liver injury.
label: Drug
Pathology

text: Determining the risk of black cohosh hepatotoxicity is further complicated by variability in both dosage and number of other botanical herbal supplements contained in some preparations.
label: Herb name
Pathology

text: As an example, in the case reported by Lontos [4], the preparation of black cohosh included 4 other botanicals: ground ivy, golden seal, gingko, and oat seeds.
label: Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Herb name
Herb name

text: While liver injury remains unreported with the use of the last 3 botanicals, ground ivy contains a known hepatotoxin, pulegone.
label: Herb name
Herb name

text: This case culminated in liver failure despite discontinuation of the herbal supplement [4].
label: Pathology

text: Drug interactions might further potentiate negative outcomes resulting from hepatoxicity due to herbal supplements.
label: Herb name

text: That subjects in 3 of 5 reported cases of autoimmune-like liver injury following consumption of black cohosh (Table 6) also had concomitant intake of synthetic thyroid hormone, levothyroxine, merits attention [2, 5].
label: Pathology
Herb name
Drug
Parameter

text: Herbal supplements such as venencapsan and black cohosh, and prescription drugs specifically rosiglitazone, ritonavir, and valproic acid, have had reported drug interactions with levothyroxine [1, 9, 18–22].
label: Herb name
Herb name

Drug

text: A 2008 review by Mahady assigned all known case reports of black cohosh-induced liver injury under the category of “possible causality” [9].
label: Herb name
Pathology

text: As earlier stated, both cases of the current study were also assigned “possible causality” by Naranjo scale [8].

Although no clinical or animal pharmacokinetic or toxicological information were identified in the Mahady review, it led to the inclusion of a cautionary statement on black cohosh products which was not previously required [9].
label: Herb name

text: Despite such development, the use of botanical dietary supplements is generally viewed by the public as safe [11].
Providers are encouraged to screen patients about their consumption of botanical herbal supplements and to assess for any evidence of liver injury [1].
label: Pathology

text: Timely discontinuation of hepatotoxic agents and, in some cases, early initiation of immunotherapy might prevent significant liver injury or could even be life saving [4].
label: Drug
Pathology

text: The validity of reported cases of liver injury due to black cohosh illustrated in Table 6 has been disputed.
label: Pathology
Herb name

text: Concerns that led to this uncertainty included cases in which the timing of liver injury occurred at a relatively short interval following exposure to black cohosh [2, 6, 7], presence of comorbidities such as cholelithhiasis [6] or concomittant use of drugs other than black cohosh that could have potentially triggered the adverse drug reaction [3, 4, 7], or the notion that some of the reported cases [2], including Case 1 of the current study (also reported by Mahady [23]), were indeed examples of autoimmune hepatitis rather than adverse drug reactions.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Herb name
Pathology
Pathology
Pathology

text: Nonetheless, application of the Naranjo causality score to these case reports found possible cause for adverse drug reaction [8].
label: Pathology

text: Further, autoimmune hepatitis is one of the known outcomes of drug-induced liver injury.
label: Pathology
Pathology

text: The immune mechanism is precipitated by a drug or a metabolite acting as a hapten covalently binding to host cellular protein, converting into an immunogen [24] and thereby eliciting an autoimmune response.
Outcomes illustrating an association of chronic hepatitis with autoimmune features developing following the use of the botanical supplement black cohosh need to be emphasized.
label: Pathology
Herb name

text: Here we described two cases of liver injury following the use of black cohosh characterized by chronic hepatitis with centrilobular necrosis and an interface activity dominated by plasma cells.
label: Herb name
Pathology

text: While the histopathology in both cases was compatible with autoimmune hepatitis, clinical evidence for an autoimmune etiology was lacking.
label: Pathology

text: Nonetheless both cases improved upon withdrawal of the drug and immunosuppressive therapy, indicating that there was at least in part a drug-induced immunological basis to the liver injury.
label: Drug
Pathology

text: The current case studies, and three other published cases of liver injury following the use of black cohosh, share similar histological characteristics [1, 2, 5].
label: Pathology
Herb name

text: Hepatic manifestations following the use of black cohosh should therefore be added to the list of differential diagnoses of hepatic necrosis culminating in chronic hepatitis mimicking autoimmune hepatitis.
label: Herb name
Pathology
Pathology
Pathology

text: This liver biopsy from Case 1 displays chronic hepatitis remarkable for its dense interface activity with cholangiolar proliferation (1a) (×200) and sheets of plasma cells and apoptosis (1b) (×600).
